author: sky.cactus
content:
It sounds like the current situation is a bit better than previously, glad we finally got some relays to share their plans with us:
Flashbots relay: Censor.
Bloxroute relay & builder: Has options that don't censor, also has options that censor.
Manifold relay & builder: Does not censor (may not be available immediately at The Merge, investigating)

author: sky.cactus
content: If Manifold can get their stuff launched with The Merge, then I would advocate that we (the Ethereum community and especially core devs) do everything we can to signal boost them as they are strongly ethos aligned.  While Bloxroute will be providing non-censoring relays, I'm a bit uncomfortable sending users their way because they *also* may be offering censorious relays.  Similar to how we wouldn't send users to a company that is actively selling viruses, malware, and scam software I think we should try to avoid supporting and signal boosting companies that are actively "selling" software that helps people censor Ethereum.

author: gwintery
content:
There wont be an censored/uncensored fork though in my understanding. Validators can choose to censor certain transactions, but eventually a non-censoring validator will pick up this transaction.

If the censoring validator insists on not attesting to certain blocks, they will be penalized out of the system

author: gwintery
content: Unless tether and circle are running more than 66% of the PoS network, they dont have much power in choosing which forks they will stay at

author: latespoon
content: They choose which chain they will back with their collateral. Stables on the other chain become worthless

author: latespoon
content: Validation of a block incudes validation of previous blocks. Therefore to remain sanction compliant, and also continue validating, they will fork

author: fradamt
content: This is just not true at the moment. Do miners currently fork away from the chain because they can't build on blocks which contain sanctioned transactions? No they don't

author: fradamt
content: Note that there is no real difference between mining on a block and attesting to a block. Both do the same thing, i.e. give that block fork-choice weight

author: gwintery
content:
I dont think this is correct. What has been spoken here so far is that some validators may censor transactions by using relays that don't broadcast certain type of transactions. They are still free to attest to blocks that contain censored transactions, but will not want to produce a block containing those transactions.

It does not mention anything about censoring an already executed transaction within a produced block, which is what you're saying. In this case, unless there is a 66% of stake that does not attest to the uncensored block, the censoring validators will eventually be ejected from the mainnet

author: latespoon
content:
As has been pointed out there is no financial penalty to miners for skipping over certain blocks or transactions.
If you attest to a new block you are also attesting to the blocks before it

author: gwintery
content: A social fork will need to be done by the community if there are only 33% of stake that does not censor transactions. As some here have said, there is little value of a censorable ethereum protocol that can bend down to the government will

author: latespoon

If 33.33% of validators refuse to attest to a block, it can't finalize...and the slashing can't be conducted as a matter of consensus....a fork becomes necessary.

Users who are taken to the soup kitchen line by slashing stay on WalmartChain while we try to defend PunkChain

author: sky.cactus
content: Depends on the specific topic.  In general, this server is not the right place for speculation about future economics.  This server is for R&D related to building a censorship resistant execution platform.  I *think* the EthStaker discord is a bit more open to that kind of discussion but I'm not certain.  And of course there is Twitter and Reddit.  There may be other places that are good to have this sort of conversation.

author: latespoon
content: Apologies. I suppose the thing is our concerns are rooted in the potential resilience of a censorship resistant eth in the event of a fork at merge, which lead me here. I'll stay on topic going forward

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think anyone is discounting your concerns, and most here probably agree with them.  It is just that this server isn't the right place to discuss the downstream effects of various actions by various market participants.  It *is* the right place to discuss how we can build censorship resistant software though.  Sometimes the line between the two is blurry, but we do try hard to keep from stepping over that blurry line.

author: uri_bloxroute
content:
I think this is an unfair definition.

*bloXroute* is not censoring anyone!
we allow validators to tell us which Tx to include in a block, and we try to do so effectively, and relay blocks from others who do so.
Would you prefer we decide for the validator which transactions to include?
Does avoiding from drowning mean they‚Äôre censoring frontrunning transactions?

This decision is *waaay* out of our league 


We are not part of the consensus, nor part of the protocol, and I don‚Äôt see how we providing flexibility to validators to decide how to construct a block put us in the ‚Äúbad guys‚Äù a bucket ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

author: sky.cactus
content: The issue is that the entire reason we build Ethereum is *very explicitly* for censorship resistance.  Supporting "partners" (very weakly using this term, happy to use another one) who are creating tools that enable censorship feels like it goes directly against our ethos, even if the partner *also* builds tools that don't censor.

author: sky.cactus
content: I *do* think that Bloxroute is much better than Flashbots on this front.  At least you aren't forcing your users to censor.

author: sky.cactus
content: To phrase things another way, if users ask "where do I find a relay" and we point them at Bloxroute, and Bloxroute then gives the user 3 options one of which is to "harm Ethereum", then it feels like we shouldn't have pointed them at Bloxroute in the first place.

author: bertcmiller
content:
As promised we have just open sourced the Flashbots Relay: https://writings.flashbots.net/writings/Flashbots-Relay-open-sourcing
https://github.com/flashbots/mev-boost-relay

author: uri_bloxroute
content:
Is this not exactly the same like condemning TC for their users using their tool to do evil/crime?

When you point validators at bloXroute, *they* are the ones making the choice‚Ä¶ are we the bad guys for offering options, and *they* choose to censor?

Who am I to tell them they should ignore OFAC and potentially suffer? I don‚Äôt even know where they‚Äôre located, what are their circumstances, or e.g. if they should or shouldn‚Äôt include front running Tx?

author: sky.cactus
content: Tornado isn't creating a tool that enables users to directly harm the core goal of Ethereum.

author: sky.cactus
content: The message we should be giving to users should be: "Either you don't censor, or you don't stake".  We shouldn't be giving them options to "censor and stake".

author: sky.cactus
content: This means the tools we should be building and promoting should be tools that allow users to stake without censoring, and we shouldn't be promoting tools that enable censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: Of course, users can do whatever they want but we shouldn't make it easy for them to undermine the precepts of the entire protocol.

author: yokem55
content:
MEV implicitly demands some censorship.

Let's say 2 transactions are presented to the mempool, both are large swaps on the same liquidity pool on a dex. Both offer ample basefees relative to what the protocol currently expects. TX A offers a higher tip, but the transaction uses tighter slippage settings. TX B offers a lower tip, but uses much looser slippage settings. The block builder sees a sandwich opportunity here and selects TX B to sandwich because the looser slippage settings allow for more profit. TX A gets included on chain a few blocks later and is reverted. 

Was TX A censored here? If not, why is the profit motive of the builder an acceptable reason to not take TX A - it offered the higher tip?

author: sky.cactus
content: I think this was a big mistake that we should be very careful to never make again.  üôÇ

author: latespoon
content:
I think the key difference there is that there's limited block space and you can pay your way into a block.
You cannot pay your way past censoring validators (afaik). It's not really the same situation.

author: bculberson
content: It becomes a problem if not enough validators will attest/vote for a slot with censored transactions right? anything up to that point would just get handled by the next non censoring validator that proposes

author: sky.cactus
content: The big problem appears if people are reorging out blocks with censored transactions.  If people are refusing to include certain transactions in their blocks that is bad, but the system can handle that.  The more people that do it, the more quality of service deteriorates for censored users but they won't be totally blocked from using the network.

author: yokem55
content: Then let's play the reverse, if the validator is ideologically opposed to sandwich attacks, and only builds naive blocks from the mempool, and takes TX A instead, was B (and the sandwich bundle author) censored?

author: lukaszrozmej
content: I'm inclining to drop MEV Boost and revert to current MEV extraction mechanism which can't force censorship.

author: dirigible6945
content: FYI, for anyone on DAG watch, we're about 2 hours away from the increase.

author: sky.cactus
content: Why do you think the current MEV extraction mechanism can't force censorship?  I believe the current FB relay that everyone is using *right now* censors.

author: latespoon
content:
Short answer: yes
Long answer: a sandwich attack is exploiting a weakness in the protocol. The ideological difference between preventing a 'nefarious' trader from exploiting a protocol user via a very specific set of transaction requirements, or a validator blanket-censoring transactions fron specific addresses are quite different. It's still censorship but, perhaps a slightly less offensive form

author: latespoon
content: Also would note that the sandwich attackers transactions would likely be allowed at any other point, bar on either side of the transaction they are targeting

author: latespoon
content: Whereas tornado users may be censored for days, weeks or permanently

author: vinnie9190
content:
Nothing is goin to happen. Vrams on either Asic or GPUs are not built in exact integer units.  A 5gb ASIC might mount a Vram in the 4.8-5.2 GB range. 0,1GB = 2 months of DAG increase.

On the GPU side, Zombiemodes can be activated in a particular way, but the only GPU I know which is 5gb is a low sold 1060 (5 yr old) not that profitable and probably quite not used vastly for mining.

author: mkkoll
content:
<@301186049323958275> Very interesting conversation around censorship today üôÇ
My take as a lowly solo-staker with a very limited # of validators is -
Everything and anyone can be sacrificed in order to maintain these two core protocol features:
1. Censorship resistance
2. Credible neutrality
The questions raised around the neutrality of mev-boost and block relayers in general has changed my opinion on whether i will run them or not. I choose not. 
I will leave the ~10% rewards from MEV on the table if it means im not proposing a censored block. Every time my validator gets to propose, it will be pretty much naive to MEV and will propose any of the tx in the mempool that it can verify follow the protocol rules. Nothing more or less.

author: mkkoll
content:
This is the stance the community should be taking wholesale.
If people are choosing to extract as much MEV as they can at the expense of the neutrality and censorship resistance of the protocol, then the protocol will fail long term.

author: mkkoll
content: And arguably, its up to the social consensus layer of Ethereum to take the ideological stance that compromising on this is anathema to the protocol and MUST NOT happen

author: tokey1475
content: I will suggest going a step further and supporting a neutral relay.  If non-censoring relays/builders don't get enough validator support, searchers will not bother sending them MEV bundles, making them less competitive with censoring relays/builders

author: mkkoll
content: Excellent point. But then i will need the expertise of how to determine if a relay is truly neutral or not üòÖ

author: mkkoll
content: i.e how do they prove they are building blocks in a neutral way

author: tokey1475
content: you are right, there isn't any infrastructure in place for that today, but it is being worked on. not running any relays until that is available is a very reasonable path IMHO

author: mkkoll
content:
Right. Block proposers have maybe the most important role in the protocol. Its why there are rewards and penalties around doing it.
I think it will be best to see how the ecosystem of relayers pans out over the few months after the merge, and not do anything as a proposer that harms the protocol.

author: yorickdowne
content: <@628018527470616606> and some others: Can I advise to gather more data. We currently do not know that OFAC require any action by block producers at all. In fact there is strong evidence they don't. We just spoke with a large US Bitcoin miner today, they do not censor tx in response to the May Blender.io OFAC action. We've asked to be put in touch with their compliance team so we can learn more.

author: yorickdowne
content: There is very likely a legal theory here that says "as a block producer only, you are not impacted"

author: yorickdowne
content: Before we tear Ethereum apart in a civil war, let's first figure out whether we have a casus belli

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree that censorship *shouldn't* be happening (for multiple reasons, including that they don't legally need to).  None the less, it is happening.  ü§∑

author: yorickdowne
content: Yeah <@976054259047088128> that's interesting but kinda adjacent, as we still have other addresses to worry about

author: sky.cactus
content: My broad argument here is that we shouldn't be building anything that enables or encourages users to censor.  Taking this a step further, we shouldn't enable, support, or signal boost any entities that build things that enable or encourage censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't actually care *why* people are censoring really at all, nor do I care why people are building software that censors.  I think neither should happen and we should push back hard anytime we see either happening.

author: darius510
content: I agree with the sentiment but you should be very careful about the way this is presented (or even discussed in public TBH.) The entity you are pushing back against is not afraid to throw people in jail for bypassing sanctions or even apparently creating just tools that can theoretically be used to bypass sanctions. This isn't theoretical, I probably don't need to remind you guys they've already done this with more than one ETH dev. You need to walk a really fine line here. There's a very big distinction to make here between "we **can't** censor" and "we **"won't"** censor" and IMO what is being discussed is getting dangerously close to the latter.

I'm surprised metamask hasn't blocked sanctioned users yet. The fact is a lot of the products that interact with/are on eth come from companies in countries with laws. So I commend you and others on trying and its definitely a great goal. I just suspect it won't happen. Companies are too embedded in crypto.

content:
Nah that's pessimistic. 

Coinbase says censor free. Other major pools go "If Coinbase isn't censoring, we're fine." Solo stakers go "If U.S. Coinbase isn't censoring, I'm fine." Majority is now non-censoring. All good
